intro: Brassica richeri, commonly known as the mountain mustard, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as broccoli and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its leaves are alternate, lobed, and often covered in a fine layer of white wax. Brassica richeri is adapted to high-altitude environments and is often found in rocky or alpine habitats.
